title: Rate cut looms on back of global turmoil
text:
China's whipsawing equity market and further declines in commodity prices have forced a rethink about medium-term risks to the Australian economy.
Another interest rate cut is on the cards as bets mount that market turmoil, lower commodity prices and continued weakness in Australian business investment will force the Reserve Bank of Australia's hand for a third time.
Economists say concerns about Greece's survival in the eurozone signal that the US will hold off on lifting interest rates for the first time in almost a decade, China's whipsawing equity market and further declines in commodity prices have forced a rethink about medium-term risks to the economy.
Australia's sharemarket lost 2 per cent on Wednesday, after another sharp decline in Chinese equities. The benchmark Shanghai Shenzen CSI 300 shed as much as 8 per cent before closing about 7 per cent down.
Accumulated losses now stand at more than 30 per cent since mid-June. Hong Kong shares also tanked, recording their worst one-day fall since the global financial crisis.
Advertisement Most analysts and fund managers caution that the drop in the mainland China index comes after a much steeper rise over the past 12 months, and that Chinese economic fundamentals remain solid.
"You could argue that China's financial market is becoming more integrated in global investor sentiment," Commonwealth Bank China and Asia economist Wei Li said.
"Panic starts to feed on itself. There may not be any direct relationship between [the markets] but they affect each other," he said.
"I still feel we are a long way from the [Chinese] equity falls having a material impact on economics," IG chief markets strategist Chris Weston said in a note.
Macquarie division director Martin Lakos said events in China were "the primary driver" of the Australian share market.
"Because China is in a local time zone it's very visible for us. In terms of our market it's certainly having an impact."
However, the turbulence, added to Greece's debt crisis and a surging US dollar has put downward pressure on the price of key Australian commodities such as iron ore, the price of which has dropped nearly 25 per cent in the last month.
The dollar also dipped below 74Â¢ for the first time in six years and economists tip it could go lower yet.
Current interest rate market pricing, which suggests a 100 per cent chance that the RBA will cut rates to 1.75 per cent on or by the April 2016 meeting, compared with a 68 per cent chance of a cut, to 1.83 per cent, just a month ago.
Some economists, too, have tweaked their outlook for the year, warning of increasing downside risks to earlier predictions that the RBA had finished cutting the cash rate in the current cycle.
Wednesday's shift in betting comes despite a benign statement on Tuesday from RBA governor Glenn Stevens, who left the door ajar for another rate cut without indicating it would happen.
